Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.2.Eg.281 - Caribbean Lowland Humid Forest EN'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.2.Eg.281 - Caribbean Lowland Humid Forest EN'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.2.Eg.281 - Caribbean Lowland Humid Forest' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.2.Eg Caribbeo-Mesoamerican Lowland Humid Forest' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Characteristic-biota.Taxon: Chamaecrista glandulosa var. mirabilis (= Cassia mirabilis)
Prestoea acuminata var. montana (= Prestoea montana)

Abiotic-environment.Summary: estación seca regular y precipitación promedio mensual de 100 mm o más. precipitaciones 1800-3200 mm, temperatura anual de 18 a 24 °C (4) Bosques en blanco suelo de arena, en suelo de arcilla o sobre piedra caliza. suelos rojos amarillentos (1) Calcáreos y suelos aluviales (2). Suelos derivados de geologías volcánicas y sedimentarias (3).suelos ferralíticos pobres (4)

Biotic-processes.Summary: Bosques húmedos con un dosel alto, cerrado y generalmente sin árboles emergentes. Especies dominantes del dosel varían de una isla a otra, 30-35 m de altura , y tres capas de árboles (1). Tiene un dosel abierto , 20-25 m de altura, con emergentes y una segunda capa más densa , 8-15 m de altura .Alrededor del 70 % de las especies del dosel son de hoja perenne. Las lianas son abundantes .Pocas epífitas tolerantes a la sequía están presentes.(2). El dosel es de 20-25 m de altura, no está densamente cerrado y emergentes son común. El segundo estrato está cerrada, y helechos terrestres dominan el estrato herbáceo . Los líquenes y briófitos crecen en troncos (3). Dos capas de dosel , en su mayoría árboles esclerófilos y lauraceous y shrubs. Dosel vegetal superior tiende a ser abierto, con un denso estrato inferior (4).

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Distribution.Summary: Bosques Humedos y Bosques Siempreverde Parte norte de Cuba oriental, norte de Jamaica, el este de República Dominicana, el norte de Puerto Rico, Trinidad y Tobago y áreas pequeñas en las Antillas Menores. Cuba , República Dominicana , Jamaica, las Antillas Menores y Puerto Rico (1). Cuba y Puerto Rico (4). Bahamas, Cuba, Jamaica, Martinique, Puerto Rico, Islas Virgenes (2). Cuba República Dominicana , Jamaica , Puerto Rico, Venezuela y las Islas Vírgenes (3)
Distribution.Biogeographic-region: WWF ecoregion 'Trinidad and Tobago moist forests'

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.

Assessment-unit.name: global

Ecosystem-subset.name: Global
Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Regional or Continental-level assessment for the whole distribution of the '1.A.2.Eg.281 - Caribbean Lowland Humid Forest' macrogroup.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: According to the evaluated indicators the threshold for EN was reached for criteria.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of recent change in woodland cover reached the threshold for EN for subcriterion A1. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A1 could be in the range of LC -- EN.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of predicted future change in tree cover reached the threshold for VU for subcriterion A2b. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A2b could be in the range of EN -- LC.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of historical change in woodland cover reached the threshold for EN for subcriterion A3. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A3 could be in the range of VU -- EN.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Assessment-unit.name: Virgin Islands

Ecosystem-subset.name: National: Virgin Islands
Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Country-level assessment of '1.A.2.Eg.281 - Caribbean Lowland Humid Forest' macrogroup in Virgin Islands.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: According to the evaluated indicators the threshold for CR was reached for criterion. Uncertainty in the indicators suggests that the overall category can be in the range os EN -- CR.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The recent changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A1.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The predicted future changes in tree cover was near to the threshold for Vulnerable. For this reason it is considered Near Threatened under subcriterion A2b.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of historical change in woodland cover reached the threshold for CR for subcriterion A3. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A3 could be in the range of EN -- CR.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.2.Eg.578 - Mesoamerican Lowland Humid Forest EN'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.2.Eg.578 - Mesoamerican Lowland Humid Forest EN'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.2.Eg.578 - Mesoamerican Lowland Humid Forest' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.2.Eg Caribbeo-Mesoamerican Lowland Humid Forest' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Characteristic-biota.Taxon: Coussapoa eggersii (= Coussapoa villosa ssp. eggersii)

Abiotic-environment.Summary: Alta precipitacion todo el año. Corta estación seca Material parental sedimentario (calizas). igneo (cenizas o basalto) y metamorficas

Biotic-processes.Summary: Bosques Denso. alto y estratificado, rico en palmas epifitas y lianas.

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Distribution.Summary: 1. Bsq. Siempreverdes, 2. Bsq. humedos semi-siempreverdes Se presenta en las llanuras costeras del Pacifico y del Caribe. Cordilleras costeras, tierras bjas, colinas bajas de America Central
Distribution.Biogeographic-region: WWF ecoregion 'Sierra Madre del Sur pine-oak forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt pine-oak forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Sierra Madre de Oaxaca pine-oak forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Sierra Madre Oriental pine-oak forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Central American Atlantic moist forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Sierra Madre de Chiapas moist forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Costa Rican seasonal moist forests'
Global 200 ecoregion 'Sierra Madre Oriental and Occidental pine-oak forests'

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.

Assessment-unit.name: global

Assessment-unit.Rationale: According to the evaluated indicators the threshold for EN was reached for criterion.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The recent changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A1. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A1 could be in the range of LC -- NT.

Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of predicted future change in tree cover reached the threshold for EN for subcriterion A2b.

Subcriterion.Rationale: The historical changes in woodland cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A3.

Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.2.Eg.873 - Mesoamerican Submontane Humid Forest EN'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.2.Eg.873 - Mesoamerican Submontane Humid Forest EN'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.2.Eg.873 - Mesoamerican Submontane Humid Forest' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.2.Eg Caribbeo-Mesoamerican Lowland Humid Forest' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Abiotic-environment.Summary: precipitación superior a 2000 mm anuales (1) Región montañosa de origen terciario con suelos molisoles, alfisoles, ultisoles, bien drenados y de alto contenido orgánico. En algunas partes puede haber afloramientos de roca, aunque no es común(1). suelos ácidos, arcillosos y generalmente bien drenados.(2)

Biotic-processes.Summary: bosques de especies latifoliadas y siempreverdes, en algunas comunidades hay palmas y en general la estructura de los bosques es compleja, con numerosas epífitas, lianas y varios estratos leñosos, además de un dosel cerrado que alcanza los 20-40 m de alto (1). constituyen una gran parte de los sistemas montanos de Panama ya que hay relativamente poco territorio sobre los 1500-1600 m de altitud.(2)

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Distribution.Summary: Bsq. humedos y muy humedos Norte de Centroamerica (1). Vertiente Atlántica en Costa Rica y de ambas vertientes en las montañas de la región occidental y las del área del Canal de Panamá (2)
Distribution.Biogeographic-region: WWF ecoregion 'Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt pine-oak forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Sierra Madre de Oaxaca pine-oak forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Central American Atlantic moist forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Sierra Madre de Chiapas moist forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Costa Rican seasonal moist forests'

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The recent changes in woodland cover was near to the threshold for Vulnerable. For this reason it is considered Near Threatened under subcriterion A1. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A1 could be in the range of LC -- VU.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of predicted future change in tree cover reached the threshold for CR for subcriterion A2b. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A2b could be in the range of CR -- EN.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The historical changes in woodland cover was near to the threshold for Vulnerable. For this reason it is considered Near Threatened under subcriterion A3. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A3 could be in the range of LC -- VU.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.
